  "bbcm": {
    "header": {
      "headline": "Press summary for Georgia's breakaway region of Abkhazia 21 Jan - 17 Feb 16",
      "catchline": "TCU-GEORGIA-ABKHAZ-PRESS",
      "broadcastDate": "17-02-2016 00:00:00",
      "publicationDate": "16-02-2016 18:42:18",
      "sourceCountry": {
        "code": "GEO",

        42.315407,
        43.356892

        42.315407,
        43.356892
      ],
      "service": {

        "service": "Summary of Abkhaz Press"
      },
      "contentLanguage": {
        "languageCode": "RUS",
        "language": "Russian"
      },
      "topics": "DOMESTIC_POLITICAL",

        "priorityCode": "RR",
        "priority": "Routine"

        "mediumCode": "PR",
        "medium": "Press"
      },
      "copyright": "BBC Monitoring. Copyright BBC."
    },
    "content": {
      "sourceline": "Summary of Abkhaz Press compiled by BBC Monitoring in Russian 17 Feb 16",
      "signoff": "BBC Mon TCU nk",
      "bodyParagraph": "Nuzhnaya Gazeta, No 1, 21 Jan /n1. Olga Jonua reports on Abkhaz president Raul Khajimba's speech in the Abkhaz parliament, in which he touched on problems such as a \"primitive structure\" of the Abkhaz economy; pubic control over government spending; taxation and a \"disastrous\" scale of tax evasion; pensions and social allowances; and repatriation of the ethnic Abkhaz living abroad; p 1; 1,500 words; npp. /n1. Unattirbuted report says that on 29 January, the Abkhaz parliament adopted amendments to the local self-government law that says that heads of local administrations are going to be appointed by president with the approval of the elected bodies of local self-government; p 2; 700 words; npp. /n2. Jof Grivapsh interviews the new head of the Abkhaz state-run TV station, Leonid Enik, who says that the role of the Abkhaz language should become more substantial in broadcasting; notes that he does not intend to make any personnel changes at the moment; and vows to allow the opposition to appear in the programmes of the TV station; p 3; 900 words; npp. /n1. Inal Khashig writes that the Abkhaz government has failed to carry out any reforms in the local management and other areas and attempts to point to reasons for the failure; p 1; 600 words; npp. /n2. Anton Krivenyuk writes that Abkhazia has joined Russian sanctions against Turkey, which, as many say, can lead to deterioration in Abkhaz-Turkish relations. However, the author notes that there are effectively no relations between Abkhazia and Turkey; p 3; 1,900 words; processing. /nNuzhnaya Gazeta, No 2, 28 Jan; Nuzhnaya Gazeta, No 4, 11 Feb - negative selection /nChegemskaya Pravda did not appear on 21 and 28 Jan and 11 Feb"
    }
  },
